comments.commentBody: How genius one must feel to find a typo in a forum and point it out. Large companies don't open their doors for a tax credit either, but they take advantage of every credit available to them.  In fact, they get to write off so much that companies never ever pay taxes, we all know that.  So it's left to me and other working class people to ask for more, because that's exactly what the business community does all day, every day.  We bail out banks, auto companies, and Wall Street, yet people question a higher education? How unAmerican.

Fran, harsh but earned. I just point to something relatively recent: his campaign sent a letter to the DNC complaining that they think, with no proof, that the Hillary Victory fund is violating election law. Then they sent an email to their supporters claiming that as fact.

Now, if they were really concerned or had any evidence, they should go to the Federal Election Commission. Instead, it was a media/bullying tactic, intended only to become a press release and to raise money on.

That looks like fraud to me.

And, the irony -- the campaign that the FEC is looking into for potential fundraising violations? The Sanders campaign.

Neither candidate has a path to the nomination without the superdelegates, and the reason the party in its "wisdom" chose to have superdelegates was so they could nominate the most electable candidate. That certainly is not Clinton if the GOP choses Kasich, and probably not Clinton if Trump cleans up his act as he is promising to do. But Sanders comfortably beats them both.

You wrote very contradictory positions about when to capitulate: "It's time to pull the party together and prepare for the General. Hillary conceded with class and threw considerable influence behind Obama in '08 once the primaries were over."

Your words are "once the primaries were over" - well they are not over until June 15th, so, following Hillary's example, the time to think about what to do next would come then, not two months earlier. Btw, I would not have called her concession speech as doing it "with class", and I believe it was done with a deal, was it not? A deal that has put the torch to the Middle East.

Despite all of the whining from Trump and Sanders, the economy has been doing just fine for the last 5 years.

Only the people who would rather complain and insist that it's the President's personal responsibility to give them cushy jobs without having to work hard or take some personal responsibility are at those rallies.

Hillary Clinton has handled trash talk for decades.  The problem with Bernie's supporters is that they have descended into trash talk.  Bernie was never a Democrat; he is now, as a convenience.  Hillary has always been a Democrat, and she spends a lot of money on down ballot races.  Her visit with George Clooney was to raise money for those races.  How much money has Bernie spent on other races?

I could not agree more, except that I have for a long time seen clearly how sexism is so ubiquitous that it operates almost invisibly...unfortunately the democratic primary is not immune to it, nor is the party. All the more reason I don't believe Sanders' rhetoric about revolution..USA needs women leaders more than anything.

I would support Bernie in a flash if he has a real chance to get the nomination. I see Hillary for who she is but I will back her 100% because I know that the critical battle is not between Hillary and Bernie. It is a fight for the last chance for even a flawed democracy to survive.

If the battle is lost to the Republicans there shall be a descent into the bottomless pit of fascism and with all three branches of government in the hands of Karl Rove, the Koch brothers and the Freedom Caucus There will be no way back..not ever. If Bernie supporters ever want to have another shot at the revolution we desperately need ...then there is no option but to fight for a Democratic win in 2016. Don't throw away everything he has fought for.

Hillary Clinton gave Sanders $10,000 when he first ran for the Senate; she helped him.  He has now been in the Senate for 26 years with a record of lots of amendments and a vote against the Iraq War.  He has never been abroad, and has never met with any important foreign leaders.  In fact, he has no foreign policy.  His domestic policy consists of plans with no funding.  He an old man running on ego.  He cannot get the nomination; he knows that.  So the rest is collecting donations and blowing smoke.

@dls
That won't work as an excuse. There's enough negativity on all sides.
Time for all to get back on message and stick to the points, instead of pointing fingers.
Good luck with that; I agree: he should. But he hasn't done much of that in his long service as a Senator. So I personally am assuming he's going to continue as he has  done. Too bad, though.
No, my compelling motive is I want to vote for a life-long progressive who is smart, tough, and on my side -- Hillary!

Yes, a very easy puzzle, especially for a Friday. But fun! "Conga" for party line; "nailgun" for sharp shooter. It took me a minute to figure out that a spreadsheet contains many cells. I am not mathematically inclined. Kind of a relief, though, since I struggled with Thursdays.

I am sorry for the disappointment felt by some of my impassioned Bernie supporting friends. But I am very pleased that maybe now we can all focus on beating the Rs. And I do think it is time for Senator Sanders to step away, donate the funds he has raised to down-ticket candidates (NOT just the three who he has a deal with!), and use his star power to help make sure that we take at least the Senate, maybe even the House, and hopefully make good ground in all the state and local races.

Now, THAT would be progressive action from him and his supporters.
Sorry - éminence grise!

Why not, the title is more in keeping with how President-General Secretary Xi views the interaction of Party and Military. There was a leaked report in the Times, from Shenzhen meeting with part elites soon after Xi came to power, and the topic was the Gorbachev problem. That is the party losing power because the military was not there to put down the protest that led to the collapse of the USSR’s CP under Gorbachev . Xi’s attention to strengthening the PLA including building up the navy has filled the news since.

The ominous news is the likelihood that C-of-C Xi will have to deal with C-of-C Trump or C-of-C Clinton in coming years. It is hard to imagine rational behavior ruling the day in such a world.

Fine, but please go find someone in some other race to whom you can give your time, energy, support.  The Presidential isn't the only race out there, and we progressives need all the wins, on all levels, we can get!

The impeachment failed.  He was never impeached.  Now, can we move past Monica Lewinsky and look at what he did in North Korea?  He got a prisoner released through his charm and diplomacy.  He has friends all over the world; he is admired all over the world.  He is a decent man, and he was a very good Democratic President.  Hillary Clinton will beat Trump and she will also be a very good Democratic President.

Hillary Clinton may not be popular with you but she is so far the most popular of all the candidates - she has received more actual votes than any of them.  In NY State, she received almost twice as many votes as Donald Trump, the Republican winner.
Many low information voters may not be aware that "praying for" is merely a figure of speech.
Or even as John McCain did, to someone at one of his campaign stops vilifying then-candidate Obama.  Surely he can do as well as Senator McCain, for someone on the same side!

Fine, but don't stay home!  There are plenty of other races out there -- find some other candidate, state, local, whoever, to whom you can give your support and effort to.  That person will be grateful, you will have fun, and we, all progressives, will thank you.   We need to take a leaf out of the R playbook and start working down ticket.
Never!  Let the NYT go!  His major enemy!  And the NY Democratic Party should drown in their pool of voter suppression of every possible kind, and their closed primary six months back!

@deus
I would also suggest that you look to see who WON as President, and then went on to win a second term.
Why??? -- Because they were real Democrats, who in the end supported the Party line --unlike Sanders who is merely a Democrat-in-name-only....And yes, there is a difference.
I just wanted to say thank you for your polite, honest and rational comment.

@dls
You are clearly not doing your candidate any favors.
